text:
Fun fact: up to this day, there are still people that think the guy issuing orders to his troops is a German who says something like 'Die Waffen, legt an!'. What they don't realize is that the developer already said years ago that he himself has no idea what the guy says and that when gamers came up with that theory, he just went along with it. ''Die Waffen, legt an'' is also not exactly a normally phrased military order.

In reality, the commander issuing orders is using American English-sounding vowels, if it were 'Waffen' it should have a very different sounding ''ah'', harsher and further to the front of the mouth. And the final word ends in a ''ch'' consonant. What the man is likely saying is something like 'reform line, quick march'. The full recording can be found here with additional commands: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=44IZfnwokMA

With the help of commenter James Lindsay who posted a while after me and MacKingsly, this is what I think is being said: 

0:11 ''Reform band (not clear, could instead be ''D Squadron'' or something), quick march!''

0:27 ''On the center'' (and usually it would be followed by ''turn'', but it might be 'dress'.)

0:42 ''Arms'', something something

0:45 ''Ready front!''  (Clearly a rhotic ''r'' sound at the beginning. I found this one - it's an actual US military drill command) source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drill_commands#United_States

0:46 ''Fall in!'' (probably) They would've done it pretty fast. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_parade#Common_parade_commands

One more useful link (thanks to MacKingsly)
http://www.calgaryhighlanderscadets.com/training/_Archived/Training_Resource_Disk/pdfs/401/40118.pdf

author: Fr0zenNightmare

text:
It most certainly is there in the game. "DIE WAFFEN - LEGT AN!" which, I believe, roughly translates from german to "WEAPONS - AT THE READY!".

The reason it sounds different is because this was taken from the official Red Alert OST CD so it's presented in the original 44 kHz stereo source quality. In the game (PC version at least), everything was downsampled to 22 kHz mono due to storage space and PC performance reasons of back then.

text: @thomasoring I agree. If there's one thing the C&C series is known for, it's NOT sticking to the same basic formula in practically every game. If there's another thing the series is known for, it's NOT making a shedful of cash with each new release. The majority of game developers stick to a winning formula. The really original games are what we call "classics" today, and it's easy to forget that they made up maybe 5% of the games of their time. And a lot of them had a shit-ton of sequels too.
